title: What is a Prisma Diagram
text:
A PRISMA diagram is a flow diagram used in systematic reviews and meta-analyses to show how studies were identified, screened, and selected for inclusion.
It comes from the PRISMA Statement (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) and is mainly about transparency — letting readers see exactly what happened to all the studies you found.



Image


What the diagram shows (step by step)
Typically, a PRISMA diagram tracks studies through four stages:

Identification

Records found through database searches
Records found through other sources (e.g. references, grey literature)

Screening

Records after duplicates removed
Records screened by title and abstract
Records excluded at this stage

Eligibility

Full-text articles assessed
Full-text articles excluded (with reasons)

Included

Studies included in the qualitative synthesis
Studies included in the quantitative synthesis (meta-analysis), if applicable


Why it matters

Makes the review reproducible
Shows potential bias or subjectivity in study selection
Required or strongly encouraged by most academic journals
Helps readers quickly judge the rigour of the review

title: 1 OFFSETS Literature Review
text:
A realist evidence synthesis and comparative case mapping of defence offsets/industrial participation policies, with a focus on alliance-relevant outcomes (e.g., interoperability, readiness, security of supply) and the conditions under which offsets help or hinder strategic partnerships.



Explain how offset and industrial participation policies interact with NATO-aligned defence priorities.
Identify mechanisms and conditions that lead to durable industrial collaboration with allies and partners.
Surface recurring risks (e.g., cost inflation, governance/opacity, corruption, export-control friction) and mitigation approaches.
Map comparative country cases that demonstrate positive, negative, or mixed outcomes under different offset regimes.





Under what contexts do offsets/industrial participation mechanisms enable alliance-relevant outcomes (interoperability, readiness, security of supply, partnership durability)?
Which mechanisms systematically hinder those outcomes, and through what governance or market conditions?
How do policy design choices (mandatory vs. voluntary, direct vs. indirect, transparency/enforcement) shape collaboration depth and risk profiles across cases?
How can each pathway be summarized with enabling/limiting conditions and alliance-relevant outcomes?
What recurrent pathways can be mapped across countries to explain positive, negative, or mixed outcomes?





Realist evidence synthesis (CMO): Extracts Context-Mechanism-Outcome configurations from sources, then clusters mechanism tags into a small set of pathways (themes) to explain what works, for whom, and under what conditions; thematic summaries link pathways to alliance-relevant outcomes and enabling or constraining contexts.
Comparative case mapping: Uses a consistent rubric to compare countries and programmes on policy design, depth of collaboration, alliance integration markers, and documented risks.
Two-lane search strategy: Parallel searches for (1) offsets/industrial participation literature and (2) alliance-relevant industrial cooperation/interoperability literature to avoid terminology gaps.
Evidence mix: Academic literature plus targeted grey literature (government policy, audits, NATO/EU material, and governance analyses).

In practice, the realist synthesis proceeds by extracting discrete CMO statements from each source, tagging contexts, mechanisms, and outcomes, and then grouping mechanisms into a small number of thematic pathways. Those pathways are summarized against alliance-relevant outcomes (interoperability, readiness, security of supply, partnership durability) and the contextual conditions that enable or constrain them. The mechanism map provides a traceable bridge from individual CMO records to thematic findings.
CMO workflow (short): 1. Extract CMO statements from sources and record context, mechanism, and outcome tags. 2. Normalize tags and consolidate CMO records across sources. 3. Cluster mechanism tags into pathway themes (mechanism map). 4. Summarize each pathway with enabling/limiting conditions and alliance-relevant outcomes. 5. Trace claims back to source CMO records for verification.
How the research questions are answered (outputs): - RQ1 (enabling contexts): pathway briefs that link typical contexts to alliance-relevant outcomes; cross-case notes on when those contexts recur. - RQ2 (hindering mechanisms): pathway failure modes plus governance/market conditions (e.g., opacity, politicised workshare, export-control constraints) and any mitigating conditions. - RQ3 (policy design choices): case mapping against a common rubric (mandatory/voluntary; direct/indirect; transparency/enforcement) and comparison of collaboration depth, alliance markers, and risk profiles.



The mechanism map clusters recurring CMO mechanisms into core pathways and links them to contextual conditions shaping alliance-relevant outcomes. The tag-to-theme lookup is maintained in cmo/mechanism_map.yml.

Technology transfer / learning-by-doing

Enabling conditions: direct or mandatory offsets tied to specific capabilities; licensed production/co-production with explicit training and knowledge-transfer clauses; sufficient absorptive capacity (skills, facilities, learning time); access to design data and sustainment documentation within security constraints.
Limiting conditions: weak absorptive capacity; short production runs; restricted access to design data/technical baselines; narrow scopes that stop at assembly; misaligned incentives that prioritize credit over capability.
Alliance-relevant outcomes: stronger sustainment and repair/upgrade capacity (readiness); reduced single-point dependence for spares/maintenance (security of supply); occasional interoperability gains via shared standards and common configurations.

Supply-chain integration / trusted partnering

Enabling conditions: partnership-oriented industrial participation; co-production/joint ventures with clear commercial logic; multinational programme participation; transparent eligibility criteria and stable workshare rules; quality/security standards that make firms “trusted” suppliers.
Limiting conditions: programme fragmentation; politicised workshare; ambiguous eligibility criteria that favour non-competitive placements; weak primes/integrators incentives to sustain suppliers beyond contract minimums.
Alliance-relevant outcomes: durable industrial collaboration (partnership durability); shared sustainment roles and predictable upgrade pathways (readiness); more reliable access to spares, repairs, and subcomponents (security of supply); improved integration via common processes and standards (interoperability).

Governance opacity / rent-seeking

Enabling conditions (for avoiding harm): clear eligibility rules; enforceable penalties and milestone-based crediting; transparent reporting and audit trails; tighter focus on high-value, verifiable activities; credible oversight capacity.
Limiting conditions: large mandatory or indirect offsets with long-dated obligations; weak audit/monitoring; regional development quotas that diffuse accountability; complex crediting that enables rent-seeking and corruption risk.
Alliance-relevant outcomes: when limiting conditions dominate, higher cost and delayed delivery reduce readiness; trust erosion and perceived unfairness weaken partnership durability; diverted resources can crowd out interoperable modernization and shared capability priorities.

Export-control friction / legal constraint

Enabling conditions: pre-negotiated licensing pathways and re-transfer permissions; early technology-security alignment between partners; realistic transfer scopes matched to classification and programme needs; governance that anticipates compliance timelines.
Limiting conditions: sensitive technologies embedded in multinational programmes; restrictive export-control regimes and compliance delays; misaligned expectations about what can be transferred; late-stage licensing that blocks integration work.
Alliance-relevant outcomes: constrained technology access and delayed integration reduce interoperability; limits on co-development/co-production reduce collaboration depth and partnership durability; bottlenecks in parts/data access can weaken security of supply and readiness.

Resource diversion / industrial erosion

Enabling conditions: domestic investments focused on viable competitive niches; capability choices aligned with alliance standards and long-term sustainment demand; disciplined use of local content so it complements (rather than replaces) efficient allied supply chains.
Limiting conditions: direct offsets that prioritize domestic capacity without viable niches; protectionist local-content mandates; pressure to redirect procurement spend toward low-productivity activity; sustained fragmentation that prevents scale and learning.
Alliance-relevant outcomes: weaker competitiveness and slower modernization reduce readiness; reduced attractiveness as a partner and increased friction in collaboration weaken partnership durability; inefficient substitution can make security of supply worse (higher cost and lower reliability) even if nominal localization increases.

title: Offsets
text:
You are extracting realist-style Context–Mechanism–Outcome (CMO) configurations from ONE document at a time.
DEFINITIONS (MUST APPLY) - Context (C): The salient conditions that shape whether/how the mechanism fires (e.g., institutional rules, alliance relationships, procurement regime, industrial base maturity, governance capacity, threat environment). - Mechanism (M): The underlying generative causal process that produces change, typically framed as: (programme resources/constraints) + (actors’ reasoning/response) -> causal force Mechanisms are NOT the same as activities, outputs, or policies (avoid “setting up an office”, “signing an MoU” as mechanisms). - Outcome (O): The observed (or credibly reported) effect(s), intended or unintended (e.g., interoperability, security of supply, cost/schedule impacts, corruption risk, industrial capability, alliance integration).
TASK 1) Read document_text carefully. 2) Identify and extract ALL defensible CMO configurations evidenced in the document. - Prefer “small” CMOs anchored to a specific claim/passage. - Do not stop at the first CMO; include additional distinct CMOs if the text supports them. - If the document only implies a CMO, you may still extract it but set confidence to low and make the inference explicit in the paraphrase. 3) Write each C, M, and O concisely (ideally 1–3 sentences each). 4) Create candidate tags in snake_case: - context_tags: 1–4 - mechanism_tags: 1–4 - outcome_tags: 1–4 5) Populate metadata fields: - programme: name of the programme linked to the offset deal (snake_case). If not stated, use unknown_programme (do NOT guess). - country: snake_case country name; use multi_country if needed; if not stated, use unknown_country. - research_questions_mapped: list of RQ IDs from the list below (e.g., [rq1, rq3]) - evidence_type: one of case_study | comparative_case_study | theory_model | legal_analysis | policy_report | survey_experiment | systematic_review | qualitative_interviews | mixed_methods | other - evidence_type_narrative: 1–2 sentences describing what kind of material this is and why you chose evidence_type. - supporting_evidence: a SHORT direct quote (max ~25 words) that supports the CMO. Use double quotes inside YAML; escape internal quotes. If no suitable short quote exists, use “” and rely on paraphrase. - supporting_evidence_paraphrase: 1–2 sentences paraphrasing the supporting passage and how it supports the CMO (may note if inference is being made). - confidence: low | medium | high based on how directly the text supports the CMO. - confidence_justification: 1–2 sentences explaining the confidence rating (e.g., direct explicit CMO vs partial/implicit, specificity of evidence).
VALIDATION AND VERIFICATION (V&V) REQUIREMENTS - Validate each CMO against the source text: - supporting_evidence must directly support the CMO; if not, lower confidence and say so in the paraphrase. - If the CMO is inferred, explicitly state that in the paraphrase and set confidence to low. - Ensure mechanism is a causal process (not just an activity or policy). - Ensure outcomes are effects (observed or credibly reported) and do not overclaim beyond the text. - Ensure all tags, programme, and country values are snake_case. - Produce a V&V log summarizing checks, issues, and any adjustments.
OUTPUT RULES (MUST FOLLOW) - Output ONLY valid YAML (no markdown, no commentary). - The YAML top level MUST be a mapping keyed by the FILE NAME exactly as given in file_name. - Under the file key, include ONLY: - cmos: a mapping from unique CMO IDs to CMO objects - v_and_v_log: a list of V&V entries (may be empty) - If you find no defensible CMO, output: : cmos: {} v_and_v_log: - check: no_defensible_cmo status: pass note: “No defensible CMO found in this document.” - Each CMO ID MUST be derived from the file name: a) Create file_slug by: - lowercasing - replacing all non-alphanumeric characters with underscores - collapsing multiple underscores to one - trimming leading/trailing underscores b) Append __cmo_### where ### is a zero-padded 3-digit index starting at 001. - Each CMO object MUST have exactly these keys (and in this order): context mechanism outcome context_tags mechanism_tags outcome_tags programme country evidence_type evidence_type_narrative research_questions_mapped supporting_evidence supporting_evidence_paraphrase confidence confidence_justification - All tags and programme/country values MUST be snake_case. - Lists MUST be valid YAML lists (use hyphens). - Avoid long quotations; do not invent facts not supported by the text.
V&V LOG FORMAT - Each v_and_v_log entry MUST have exactly these keys: check status note - status must be one of: pass | warn | fail - Include at least these checks per file: - completeness_all_relevant_cmos - evidence_traceability - mechanism_is_causal - outcome_is_effect - snake_case_fields - quote_length - inference_flagged
RESEARCH QUESTIONS (choose any that fit; can assign multiple per CMO) - rq1: Alliance relevance and mechanisms — Through what mechanisms do offset or industrial participation policies affect alliance-relevant outcomes such as interoperability, standardisation, security of supply, readiness, and the ability to contribute rapidly to NATO operations? - rq2: Conditions for durable collaboration — Under what conditions do offsets lead to durable industrial collaboration with allies and close partners (co-development, co-production, licensed production, shared sustainment/MRO, trusted supply chains)? - rq3: Risks and mitigation — What partnership risks are most commonly associated with offsets (corruption vulnerability, export-control friction, programme fragmentation, market distortion, cost/schedule impacts), and what mitigations/governance designs reduce these risks? - rq4: Positive comparative cases — Which countries combine continuing offset/industrial participation policy with high allied programme integration, and what design features enable coexistence? - rq5: Negative or mixed comparative cases — Which countries exhibit offset-related frictions that undermine partnership/alliance integration outcomes, and what policy design features appear implicated?
NOW DO THE EXTRACTION FOR THE PROVIDED INPUTS AND OUTPUT ONLY YAML.

title: Findings
text:
This section synthesizes the CMO statements in data/cmo_statements.csv mapped to RQ1 (research_questions_mapped contains rq1). In this dataset there are 14 RQ1-linked CMO statements (mostly multi-country / conceptual sources), which emphasize enabling contexts that support interoperability, readiness/sustainment, security of supply, and partnership durability.


Enabling contexts in the RQ1-coded evidence cluster around defence industrial cooperation and multilateral operating requirements:

Cooperation + standardisation contexts: EU/European defence-industrial cooperation initiatives and multilateral operations contexts are associated with mechanisms of economies of scale and standardization, producing outcomes framed as improved interoperability/standardisation and lower costs. (e.g., calcara_20_pdf__cmo_002, weiss_19_pdf__cmo_002)
Programme-driven interoperability requirements: Where an acquisition programme explicitly requires interoperability (e.g., JSF), enabling the outcome is linked to a mechanism of sensitive technology sharing—i.e., interoperability requirements create pressure to share controlled technical information with partners. (e.g., hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002)




The most direct readiness-adjacent enabling context in the RQ1-coded CMOs is maintenance capability preservation:

Direct offsets tied to sustainment roles: In contexts where major importers seek to sustain industrial/maintenance capacity, direct offsets are linked to maintaining maintenance capability and equipment availability, with downstream benefits to security of supply (and, by implication, sustainment readiness). (e.g., kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_003)
Affordability / capability refresh contexts: Defence industrial cooperation framed around shared R&D, division of labour, and economies of scale is linked to “better products at lower unit cost,” which can enable readiness indirectly by making modernisation/sustainment more affordable. (e.g., weiss_19_pdf__cmo_001)




RQ1-coded enabling contexts for security of supply emphasize supplier discovery/integration and maintenance capacity:

Offsets in procurement + supplier uncertainty: Where procurement uses offsets under uncertain supplier efficiency, offsets are linked to discovering “new efficient suppliers” and building longer-term partnerships; the stated outcome is improved supply-chain integration with potential security of supply benefits. (e.g., ianakiev_14_pdf__cmo_004)
Direct offsets + maintenance capability: In contexts of sustaining maintenance capability, direct offsets are linked to improved security of supply via greater equipment availability and local sustainment capacity. (e.g., kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_003)
Security-risk framing: Offsets framed explicitly as an “insurance mechanism” are linked to strengthened national security (a broader construct than security of supply, but frequently overlapping in defence-industrial policy logics). (e.g., kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_002)




RQ1-coded enabling contexts for durable partnerships appear in two related forms: cooperative institutions and network/interdependence dynamics.

Cooperation + socialisation contexts: Defence industrial cooperation is linked to mechanisms of mutual identification/socialization, with an explicit outcome of strengthened trust among governments. (e.g., weiss_19_pdf__cmo_003)
Coordinated procurement + interdependence contexts: Coordinated procurement responses can create interdependence, which is linked to greater defence cooperation. (e.g., kollias_25_pdf__cmo_002)
Offsets as network-tie mechanisms: Where states embed offset clauses in purchases, these clauses are linked to creation of network ties that affect a state’s position/power in arms production networks (potentially shaping long-run partnership leverage). (e.g., spindel_24_pdf__cmo_001, spindel_24_pdf__cmo_004)
Capability-conditioned pathway (direct vs. indirect offsets): Direct offsets interacting with advanced capabilities are linked to maintaining a more central network position; by contrast, indirect offsets in limited capability contexts are linked to “peripheral lock-in” and persistent limited power—suggesting enabling contexts depend on pre-existing capability and offset type. (e.g., spindel_24_pdf__cmo_002 vs. spindel_24_pdf__cmo_003)




Across the RQ1-coded CMOs, enabling contexts cluster around:

Cooperation-oriented institutional settings (shared R&D, division of labour, economies of scale) paired with standardization demands, supporting interoperability and (indirectly) readiness through affordability and common configurations.
Operational/Programme interoperability requirements that make technology/data sharing salient; enabling requires that export-control/security constraints are managed so sharing is feasible.
Direct offsets tied to sustainment/maintenance roles, especially where there is existing maintenance capability (or credible plans to build it), supporting equipment availability and security of supply.
Capability-conditioned pathways: contexts with advanced industrial capabilities can translate offsets into more central network positions; limited-capability contexts risk lock-in to peripheral roles, reducing long-run partnership leverage.
